utterances.utterance: But, but, but. That's more buts than that Tommy John underwear commercial we keep playing everyday. They are snug, though. But hey, when the media keeps saying but, it's because they're talking out of their asses, which is why everything they say stinks. That's a little analogy I probably should've let die, Sandra. I apologize for that.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: I don't think there's anything wrong with the buts. Here's the problem. Those buts are not bad. Those are questions. And it's reasonable to ask questions in the wake of this. Even Joe Lieberman, we were talking about him on this program yesterday in the Wall Street Journal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Great butt.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: I don't know. Why can't Democrats admit that Soleimani's death makes us safer? He said that is a question that we should all be asking, and he was asking of his fellow Democrats. The buts are a bag (ph), Greg.  As Americans, we should all have questions. That is why Congress is being addressed right now and tomorrow, so that they can let them know what the intelligence was and what ultimately lead to this decision. Going back to Elizabeth Warren, though, she was following Bernie Sanders.  He was the first on the campaign trail to use the assassin verbiage, right?  Liz Warren then followed. First, she called him a murderer. Then, she said this is the assassination of a senior military official.  She was then asked by Meghan McCain on The View three times whether or not -- would you like to play?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I would love to play it.

utterances.speaker: SANDRA
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Let's do that, Sandra.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: A terrorist?

utterances.speaker: MEGHAN MCCAIN, THE VIEW CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: You issued a statement calling Soleimani a murderer. Later, you issued a second statement saying that he was, quote, Issued a statement calling Soleimani are murderer and a second statement saying "an assassination of a senior foreign military official." I don't understand the flip-flop.

utterances.speaker: ELIZABETH WARREN (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: This isn't a change. They're truth. The question is what is the response that the president of the United States should make?

utterances.speaker: WARREN
utterances.utterance: He's part of a group --

utterances.speaker: MCCAIN
utterances.utterance: But is he a terrorist?

utterances.speaker: WARREN
utterances.utterance: He's part of a group that's been designated --

utterances.speaker: WARREN
utterances.utterance: Of course he is.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Excellent timing on that, Greg, but I'll tie it all together then.  Joe Lieberman -- and to what you just saw from Elizabeth Warren there. I think at the end of the piece in the Wall Street Journal, he asks, don't Democrats risk looking weak in the face of evil like this and not being able to make an admission like that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, first of all, let me just say I am not going to fall for your flattery, Greg. My butt is my business. But I don't have a real but here, because I don't think Soleimani was a bad guy, right? Nonetheless -- I didn't say but.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I do think that it's irrational, as you were saying to ask about ramifications, consequences, and the like. Are we safer as a nation?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, even you said just a moment ago that they are asking questions about what is to come.

utterances.speaker: LAWRENCE JONES, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.utterance: -- do believe he was assassinated?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, because that would be extralegal. And I think that's what it's about, Lawrence. If you use that term and you're talking about taking an extra legal step, my question about it is this, if you're saying -- listen, he was a terrorist and he is an enemy of ours, an enemy of the American people, if we start killing all the bad guys, we've got a lot of people to kill. Are you going to go after Vladimir Putin? You want to go after some of these folks in Latin America?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I think the president said today they kill our people, and then we have to be sensitive to them and their culture? That's exactly what he said.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I have that tape, too. My goodness, you people are on top of things. Do we have that tape or did today I dream that?

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, UNITED STATES PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: His past was horrible. He was a terrorist. He was a monster. And he is no longer a monster. He is dead.  And that is a good thing for a lot of countries. I don't anybody can complain about it. I don't hear too many people, other than politicians who are trying to win the presidency. Those are the ones that are complaining.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Then you got the AP that are -- they played video on their Twitter page of the supreme leader crying. You have Michael Moore pinning an apology to the supreme leader. You have the New York Times writing their obituary. It is like this guy wasn't a terrorist and killing over 600 of our troops.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Everything you just said is news. Everything you just said is news. When you have the supreme leader reacting in that way to the man's death that is informing us about the reaction on the ground. How about the big protests?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Should we be apologizing to them?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Here's my point. Here's the point I was trying to make. Is the U.S. safer? Is Israel safer? Without the Iran deal, are we safer? Are we in a better position to fight ISIS?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second, then. Tell me what the immediate threat was, because this guy has been going about plotting terrorist --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's true, he has.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: In the past, they killed people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What was the immediate threat there?

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.utterance: Enough public information, Reuters has an amazing piece out about how Soleimani was Iraq in September and October sitting across the U.S. embassy in Baghdad, and talking about the way that they were going to use new Iranian militias that have not yet been detected by the United States to go after American troops both in Iraq and all over the region. So there's plenty of public information on that. The problem is not asking questions about what might happen next. The issue is that you are insinuating that the president and his entire administration isn't thinking about that, and that he didn't think through that if we take this guy out, and -- who was also in the car, who was another terrorist who was a really bad actor, smuggled in most of the IEDs from Iran to Iraq that blew up our troops, he was in the car as well. The intelligence on where they were at the right time was good. So now we are questioning, you know, what's going to happen next, of course. But the idea that we don't know or have a plan leading up to this is ridiculous.  And also, they keep saying, well, the president is incompetent. He doesn't know what the Iranians are going to do, blah, blah, blah. They've been on this guy. And they understand that the Obama administration appeased the regime over and over again. Soleimani had sanctions taken off of him as a result of the Iran deal, as a result of Barack Obama's negotiation on that deal. And yet, here we are today questioning whether Trump was the one who was appeasing the Iranians?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: You were one of the Democrats saying President Trump always questions our intelligence agencies.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a minute.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a minute. Wait a minute. Stop the presses. Stop everything. Juan Williams is going to quote Tucker Carlson. Tucker Carlson said wait a minute. It was people like Lawrence who are saying this is the deep state. We can't cross the deep state. They're terrible.  Now, we love the deep state. Tucker Carlson, hats off!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It is, but the thing is I think that you can say both things.  You don't have to trust any intelligence. You don't have to trust it. But you can still kill the guy. You can do both.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Your point was we don't trust the president, because we think the president isn't thinking this through.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This president put sanctions, economic sanctions on, and had they had any effect, if so, why did he have to kill Soleimani?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: They have in fact. And the idea that we need to go is right now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I want to thank Juan for laughing at my joke about the page.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I want to thank Sandra for her compliment.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We are very civil here at The Five. All right, coming up, Bernie borrowing a page from Trump to bash Biden, that's next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's turning into a 2020 brawl. Bernie Sanders and Joe Biden locked on a growing feud over who can defeat President Trump. And now, Sanders has taken a page right out of Trump's playbook. He is attacking Biden.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: Joe Biden has been on the floor of the Senate, talking about the need to cut Social Security or Medicare or Medicaid. Joe Biden pushed a bankruptcy bill, which has caused enormous financial problems for working families. To get turnout, you need energy and excitement. And I just don't think that that kind of record is going to bring forth the energy that we need to defeat Trump.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So I think we got about less than 30 days to go before Iowa.  And you can start to see now that there is warfare among the Democrats.  They haven't been running ads attacking -- the attacks start. The question is with Biden and Bernie Sanders at the top of the pack. Are Bernie's attacks powerful enough to bring down Biden, Sandra?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Does he have the branding power that Donald Trump had? You have to go back to 2016. Who did he brand low-energy? Donald Trump, who did he brand -- Jeb Bush. Bring the low-energy person, very low-energy, very low- energy kind of guy, bring back please clap moment, remember all of that?  Donald Trump had that power to brand the candidates. We will see if he has the ability to do that. They are going to need energy, though. And when it comes to the senators that are running for president, and an impeachment trial coming, and if it looks like the Bill Clinton trial, you are talking every day, six days a week, all afternoon.  I mean, how is Bernie Sanders going to manage that? I mean, he's going to -- he can easily be opening himself up for criticism.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Lawrence, let me take you through Bernie's attack. The number one attack was about foreign policy. He said that, in fact, Biden had voted wrong on the Gulf war. He opposed it. Then he voted for the Iraq war. Of course, many Americans and certainly most Democrats think that was a mistake, no weapons of mass destruction and the like. And therefore, he says all these claims that he knows so much about foreign policy, hokum.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Well, yeah, he's a flip-flop. He's low-energy. You know, this is a guy that's been in politics into his 20s. He's been in the Senate since in his 30s. He has a long track -- he doesn't what he believes. That is the problem. If you go to the campaign rallies as I've been going to, the crowds are empty. And the people that say they want to vote for him are just saying he is just the best guy.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: You're talking about Biden?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Right, Biden, right. He just is the best candidate to be Trump. That is it. They have no policies that they support him really. They just think he is the best electable. Then you've got Bernie Sanders, who the Democrats should have gotten rid of a long time ago because he is a socialist. And he has hijacked their party. He came back with supporters. He got AOC and the Squad with him now. And now, that is the energy. And so, you're -- Biden is going to be the nominee without a doubt. You can look at the polls. They're not shifting.  But he's going to much damage because those energy people, they're not going to come out and support Biden. Watch what I tell you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That is part of Bernie's argument, Katie. And the other part of it is if you look at something like NAFTA, he will say, hey wait a second.  Joe Biden voted for NAFTA. How is that going to play in Michigan? How is that going to play in Wisconsin, Western Pennsylvania?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That's why you see people like Elizabeth Warren saying she is going to vote for the USMCA, right? But Bernie Sanders, they tried to get rid of him in 2016, completely failed. And he came back even stronger.  And when you look at the grassroots effort, the fundraising numbers that are almost double what Joe Biden is bringing in, that translates into people on the ground are going to vote. And that is why you've seen President Obama with this rift in the party, the populist, non-establishment, grassroots versus the establishment, which is Joe Biden, him coming out and saying, look, I'm not endorsing everybody.  But I just want everybody know when there's a nominee we have to get behind them. Because you are absolutely right. The Bernie Sanders faction of the party and Elizabeth Warren's faction are so far left that they're worried that they will not come out and vote for someone like Joe Biden in order to beat Donald Trump. And then couple that with the problem of electability, and they banked on that before with Hillary Clinton. It doesn't always work.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. So Greg, here is the thing. A lot of people -- and what you often deride as the mainstream media --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They make me sick, Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They are disgusting.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He's been sick. So piling onto your joke, they also often discount Bernie. We just heard Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I agree.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But Bernie has the donors and he has the poll numbers.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what, and you hit the right point. It's the media that believes they decide this, the way they decided Hillary, right? CNN decided that Bernie Sanders wasn't going to be the candidate, so they screwed him. And I think what they are trying to do now is they can't admit this could happen. But Bernie deserves this, and he really does. And he's right about Joe being low-energy. Joe is like a pen that's almost out of ink. So when you're writing -- you know you have a pen that's almost out of ink, then you put it down for a little bit, and you have to wait. Give it a little nap and you bring it up and it's back. He's like a car that requires the push of all your neighbors up the street to get it started.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: If you're right then Biden will be the nominee.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, because this --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I think it's going to make the convention.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's going to be a broken convention, and that is when Michelle comes in.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: More Hillary.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, it's going to be Michelle and Mayor Pete.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Hey. It is mid-summer dream? No, mid-winter dream here for the convention.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: I don't want to dream about Hillary.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Some of the media are not happy with Ricky Gervais after his takedown of Hollywood at the Golden Globes. We are going talk about it.  Have fun with it, have fun with all those rich, fancy, famous people right here next on The Five.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Comedian Ricky Gervais is being criticized after his takedown of Hollywood elites.

utterances.speaker: RICKY GERVAIS, COMMEDIAN
utterances.utterance: Well, you say you're woke, but the companies you work for, I mean unbelievable, Apple, Amazon, Disney. If ISIS started a streaming service, you would call your agent, wouldn't you? So if you do win an award tonight, don't use it as a platform to make a political speech, right? You're in no position to lecture the public about anything.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yup, he went there. Some media outlets are panning that performance as offensive, and others saying that nobody cared. One Vanity Fair writer even accusing the comedian of repeating a, quote, "right wing talking point." Ricky Gervais, however, is hitting right back on Twitter, saying, how the bleep can teasing huge corporations and the richest, most privileged people in the world to be considered right wing? Does he have a point, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Number one, Ricky Gervais isn't a right-winger. He is a strong, outspoken liberal. He doesn't like Trump. But the thing is this isn't about right or left. This is about freedom of expression. And I think what should be uniting conservatives and liberals, or whatever stripe, is the rift that is going on among liberalisms between free expression and those who want to silence people on campus. And that is where Ricky Gervais is coming from. If you read his Twitter feed, he is expressing his own personal outrage over the cancel culture, about how people are constantly being attacked for things that they are saying. And it's very healthy that it comes from him, from somebody on the left. Nobody -- no liberal is going to listen to be because you're just going to say, Fox News, that guy, he trashes everybody. And, you know, they are right. But when he comes out and he is upset, Ricky Gervais is upset, because he is so confident in his liberal ideas that the refusal to listen to other ideas, which is happening right now in the regressive left, enrages him. It's an emphatic (ph) sign of weakness.  So it's the hard left that is actually destroying liberalism, not Trump-ism or not conservatism. And I think that's what is fuelling his fire and why he is so disgusted and angry. But do not mistake that for him becoming a conservative. He is as liberal. And the only politics he is really into, and very strongly, is animal rights. This is a guy who spends a lot of time dealing with humane issues with animals. But it's really about the rift between old-school liberals like Juan and the social justice creep that is trying to silence people like Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I would agree, because I have been muzzled.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So I understand what it is. And in that point, I would say yes.  By the way, I didn't even know who Ricky Gervais was.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How dare you, the best sitcom ever, The Office.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I just didn't get it. I mean -- but around here, he is a star right now because of what he did. But the question is, one, do you really think that people didn't make political speeches after he spoke?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They did.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They definitely did, so I don't think it had that impact. I think the impact he had was on people who are conservatives that finally here is somebody voicing --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- disdain for these rich, famous, arrogant people want to tell us.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: But Juan, back to the point, though. They're criticizing -- the Hollywood elites are criticizing him for right wing talking points. And he said what about going after large corporations and the rich, wealthy Hollywood actors --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That was the point of what he did, to say this is legitimate speech and it's free speech coming from the left, hats off. But to the contrary, the support for him is coming from the right, which sees it as he was out there --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: -- listening to the Dave Chapelle's of the world. This is about the mob. This is about -- people are so sick and tired of everything in their life being controlled by their past or if they decide to take a joke.  I have friends of mine that are -- majority of my friends are liberal. They tell me that they can't share a post that they may agree from Fox News because they'll get fired or they won't be invited to the next get together or something because that's how the mob works. And this is a guy who's a liberal that just wants freedom of expression.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes. He's speaking out against the mob, but it's also about the fact that what he said was true. He's calling them out on behavior that they lecture the rest of America about not doing while they engage in it, and it's about elitism. They're allowed to do whatever they want, while the people that they think are not good enough or not rich enough, or aren't in the Hollywood Liberal circles, they're not allowed to participate for -- but that they have to be quelled and do what they think is the right thing to do, whether it's climate change or health care or anything else like that. And Ricky Gervais is a Liberal. He's not a woke leftist. And I think this is something that is pervasive throughout comedy, but also just for the roles in general. And by the way, there are people complaining about woke leftist but they also have the reaction.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: He tweeted out best reaction ever. It means a lot to me. I had a blast and thank (BLEEP) it's over.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What do you think they bleeped there, Sandra?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: I don't know, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What does it rhyme with?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Use your imagination. All right, up next, cities now targeting dollar stores. Why some communities want to ban them?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Nanny State Progressives have set their sights on a brand new target, dollar stores. Cities reportedly now moving to crack down on and in some cases ban discount stores that millions of Americans shop at. They blame the stores for people's poor diets. "Communities like Oklahoma City, Tulsa, Fort Worth, Birmingham, and George's DeKalb County have passed restrictions on dollar stores prompting numerous other communities to consider similar curves. New laws and zoning regulations limit how many of these stores can open and some require those already in place to sell fresh food." Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what this reminds me of -- and Juan is more closer in age than any of these people, when strip clubs, these stores are now -- like stores that sell inexpensive food to low-income families are now seen as like a pollutant in society. Like we're not having that strip club and -- but if you do, you're going to have the parking out back so we don't see everybody's cars because then we recognize everybody. Did you ever notice that, strip clubs? They always have the car parking lot in the back so can't see your husband's car.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: No, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know what I started thinking about. But the problem here is overabundance, right? We have solved hunger. And I know that people say, people go to bed hungry. But if you got to look at the statistics, you know, people are eating. And if you go and look in the street, you can tell people are eating. If you've walked down a cereal aisle, we have more -- there's different brands for every star in the sky. That's the issue here. But making it harder for low-income people to get their food which is probably high in carbs, that's not going to make their lives any easier.  You got -- and it smacks of elitism to think that because you don't shop at the dollar store, they shouldn't shop at the dollar store. Because you can afford the kale at Whole Foods, you know, they can't have macaroni and cheese at the dollar store. Sorry, when you have kids and you're on a fixed income, the dollar store is the place you're going to go. So you got to leave them alone, and maybe education at some point.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I've been shopping at the dollar store forever. So, you know, shouldn't they be encouraging the government more competition and to have more grocery stores coming in next to the dollar store rather than trying to ban and rezone which only increases prices on everything?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Well, they could do that, or they could stick with their talking point, which is Democrats want everything to be affordable, right. And the Dollar Tree, I grew up on the Dollar Tree. It wasn't a place that we got food from but we got everything else from the Dollar Tree. And I think that the Democrats are actually stepping on their message with this because a lot of people need this stuff and they can't afford to go to the other places to get --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Especially if they're heavily taxed by Democrats.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Exactly. But there was also a study done about this, and it was in the Quarterly Journal of Economics. And they did a survey of all these places that had grocery stores, and the people end up not even going to the grocery stores. So again, I think they're stepping up -- stepping on their own message. And another thing, just because things are affordable, and we knew this when we shopped at the Dollar Tree, doesn't mean that it's quality, right?  The people know that they're not looking for quality, they're looking just something -- for something to get the job done, where they at -- where they're at financially.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So Juan, one thing that the government doesn't want to ever talk about is the fact that the obesity crisis in America is their fault by subsidizing sugar, by doing the food pyramid --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: -- by telling people to eat things that they shouldn't. For decades, the government has been responsible for making people overweight.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The pyramid was a lie, Juan, just like the moon landing.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It's a total lie, it creates generations obese people. And now we have them again coming in and forcing the free market out on things that people can actually afford because they again think they know better about what Americans should be eating.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm taking this argument in. But I do think that ethanol for example -- like ethanol, I think I don't know why I pump that into my car except for the government is subsidizing farmers. And I think it's the similar thing with that emphasis that you're talking about with the food pyramid.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes, and the sugar subsidies.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But here's my feeling about this is that there really are food deserts. And so yes, I've stopped to shop at -- I think the food version of the dollar store is Dollar General. And when you go in there, you know what, man, the cuts of meat, they're all fatty, you can't find fish, you can't find fresh vegetables and fresh fruits.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, I love that.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: So what are you suggesting though?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because it has an economic impact, to pick up on Greg's point about the strip store. If you have drug dealers in the neighborhood, it makes it more difficult, Sandra, for people to have retail stores. And if you have a dollar store there, people are going to say well, everybody is going to go to the --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Juan, you can't (INAUDIBLE) on sale.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. But what I'm saying to you is everybody is saying it's cheaper and, you know, I'll fill up on this, they don't go to stores that in fact offer more nutrition, better quality food. And I guess that makes a difference in your life and your --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I grew up on that. I turned out just fine.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You're different at all.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Juan, you believe in a free market, you believe in capitalism --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's tall, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm short, I ate better than him.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: -- when you're talking about banning stores and deciding what's best for people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, wait a second, wait a minute, hold on, Sandra. I believe in the free market, but the free market does have some negative consequences like we're talking about the strip store or we could talk about prostitution in your neighborhood. This has a bad impact on your neighborhood.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I can't -- I can't say there's prostitution coming out of the dollar store.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I didn't say that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a hell of dollar store.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Stay at it --

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Juan, I think you have to acknowledge that there is a lot of people in this country who are out of touch with families that are living paycheck.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That's exactly --

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Who go into these stores and it is a convenience for them to not think about how much they can spend. If they know they have $10.00 in their pocket, they can buy 10 things.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, they will spend -- they will spend the $10, but it's going to be more potato chips, high sugar, high salt --

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: And you -- and you know better how they should use their money.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. It's not that I know --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What stores would --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: (INAUDIBLE) said no giant cokes or whatever, remember that? I don't think that is the right approach because it takes away choice but it doesn't --

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: There is concern that they're making decisions because the dollar stores are undercutting other retailers --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what I'm saying to you. It undercuts the possibility of a better quality food store --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: No, because the study shows, Juan, that when they put those stores, that people didn't go there because -- by the way, by the way, the second thing is, is that if you have those stores there and people aren't buying those products, that product goes bad, it's perishable, which means that business is not --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's like cinnamon Pepsodent. Nobody buys cinnamon Pepsodent so it ends up at the Dollar Tree.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: What I will say -- what I will say about the economics of the stores because there's a lot of research on them, do your research.  Because sometimes the dollar store, even though it's a dollar, it's a smaller quantity, and it may be cheaper at another store, I'm not saying this is the best option, but it should be an option for people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Correct. And even what Lawrence said is not good -- anyway, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The "FASTEST SEVEN" is up next.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. Time for the "FASTEST SEVEN." All right, first up, robots are supposed to make life easier, but we can figure out if this is cool or creepy. Take a look at this Samsung tiny new personal assistant named Ballie.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Ballie patrols your home to keep you safe. He is a fitness assistant, a new friend to your kids, and pets, and a camera that records and stores special moments.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Creepy.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Why do we need this, Sandra?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I can't wait.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: It's kind of weird, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. It's like the beginning of a great horror film.  But we think about it -- you know, think about you know how technology changes the present and the past. Imagine 2100, when your great-grandkids look at pictures of our time, they go wait, humans carried your luggage?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That is disgusting. Humans actually drove you to the airport?  You're slave drivers. How dare you? Because right now what's going to happen is technology is going to do all of these things and we're going to look really bad.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: But Katie, it looks like -- it looks like we're trying to find the issue like why do we need this?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Last time we talked about robots in the show I got in big trouble so --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What did you say?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to say what I say.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What did you say? Just turn a glass of water on him.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I said, throw them away. I did this. Get rid of them. They're bad.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: See, that's robotics. When they become conscious -- when they become conscious, you're going to be seen as bigot and they're going to come for you.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I don't care about their feelings. It's fine. I have a shotgun.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Can I leave?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That's good. That's good. What do you think about this?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The robots, they're going to come attack me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think the next step actually is implanted, right? They got this thing rolling around your house following you, taking your picture. I just think that's crazy. But guess what, I think it's going to be a required accessory for the upper class very shortly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And it's going to be cheap -- it's going to get cheaper, everybody laughing.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: All right, next up, a Florida woman ended up in jail over McDonald's dipping sauces. When employees tried to charge her for extra sauce, she threatened them by "any means necessary."

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: She wanted that sauce.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Yes. She's trying to get them.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: I have a similar thing with wasabi at sushi restaurant. It's the more the better for me. And I was -- they kind of looking at me funny when I asked for extra. So any means necessary.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm just happy that it's -- finally it's a Florida woman. I'm so tired of the Florida man. It's always the Florida man who's doing things.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Fair enough.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But McDonald's shouldn't run out of sauce.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I don't like this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's like me running out of analogies here.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: They charge -- but they charge you for the sauces. That's the deal. Like Chick-fil-A gives you the sauces. I take this --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: This is flying. Like just charge me the full amount.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Don't charge me the extra. Like put the cost of the sauce in the menu, you know.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I don't want to pay extra.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Sometimes you like to soak the chicken in the sauce. I don't think you should be judged for.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sometimes I don't even use chicken.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The packets are too small too.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I love you as a rapper. Katie, I'm loving it. I'm loving it at McDonald's.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: (INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, I just -- I don't understand why anyone gets so excited about it. I don't think they charge you more for the wasabi, but I mean she is going to come back and threaten people Malcolm X style by any means necessary?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Well, maybe she shouldn't have threatened them, but I mean this --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You shouldn't have hurt --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That was -- that was me this morning.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: She should not have threatened them, Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: But I understand her frustration. All right, finally, it's a movie so bad you have to get high to get through it. The Washington Post talked to people who took mind-altering drugs before going to see Cats. Some said they love the experience but one review called it the most terrifying experience of my life.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Was that the movie -- was that person on the drugs or not because the movie got horrible ratings.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I think it was terrible. I didn't get to see but I saw some of the previews and said I would never go see that.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You're judging a movie by its cover, Lawrence?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm judging it by its fur. You know, it's -- it is weird because when you take a drug while watching Cats, it immediately turns it into a normal film like Bond film or -- I take drugs when I watch Love Actually.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's because you hate that movie.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I do.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: I don't ever take drugs lightly.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Sandra, should --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You mean you're a moderate user?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: I don't drug use. I don't treat it like that.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: But should we keep Broadway on Broadway and not in the theater? I mean, that's just me.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes. I agree. I saw a mess in that theater and that was really rough.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It's bad.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan goes to plays all the time.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I do. I do.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I'd like them in person. Broadway is great. But you know, it doesn't always translate well.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Would you go see this right here?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: My wife went to see it.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: What does she think?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think the company gave her the free tickets and she said she couldn't take it. She said, if I was there, I would have walked out.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: She speaks her mind.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: She did.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She just got her in trouble too. That company is not giving her anything.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think -- anyway, I do think that if you went to see like the Joker, which is one of the top movies, right, or John Rich which is that violence --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That's a good movie.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: John Rich, no, John -- that's the country music singer.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, no, no, no.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Richard Jewel.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Anyway, a lot of these movies, I think the young people go in there and they are high you know, because I mean, that's the way they got them.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: If I got to get high to -- I don't do drugs, but if I had to get drugs to see a movie, I'm not going to go see it. That's just the bottom of it. Anyway, we got to go. "ONE MORE THING" is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Back with "ONE MORE THING." I'm going to go first. Greg's animals on Roombas. All right, I have three videos of animals on Roombas.  You guys get to vote after we get through them on which one's the best.  Let's go to number one. Check out first animal on Roomba. Looks like it's a baby Billy goat working around the old farm garage in Florida. Do farms have garages? I don't know. He seems like he's a bit confused but he's doing OK there. Check him out. Why don't we go to the second Roomba candidate? This is a hideous little opossum. You know what, he looks like a demon pope.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's nasty.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Like he looks like -- he looks like a vampire, very hairy, but they're cute when they're babies, aren't they?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: No, they're not.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No they're not, opossums? OK, finally, this is my favorite.  Let's go to this little sucker here. He's got the right look. He's doing like a centerfold for vintage playboy enjoying on his -- on his belly there. He looks like he's stirring it which I find especially. OK.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Oh, he's relaxed.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's relaxed. All right, Katie?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Bulldog.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Bulldog, one.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a minute, you can't pick favorites. You can't bias the jury. I'll go with number one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The goat. Lawrence?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: The dog.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Oh that poor opossum, I'll take it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I got to go with the Bulldog, so I think the Bulldog wins. All right, now it's you, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. And you know, there's Super Bowl wins, there's NBA Finals wins, World Series wins, and then there's Matt Driscoll win. Watch as Matt crosses the finish line after winning a three and a half year fight with acute leukemia. The 19-year-old had been undergoing chemotherapy for years during which his weight fell almost 60 pounds, leaving at one point weighing less than 100 pounds. The former athletes stayed in touch with friends and family including his high school football team. The players they were pumped up to hear their former teammate now wants to get back to playing football and basketball.  Congratulations, Matt, from all of us here at Fox on winning the fight of your life. He's cancer-free folks.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Way to go, dude. Look at that. That's good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sandra, what you got?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: All right, so you know you go to the checkout at CVS Pharmacy --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: And the receipts this long. Well, someone on Etsy has gotten very creative and there are sellers that are capitalizing on it. They're making scarfs that look like the long CVS receipts. There's even a customizable option where buyers can print anything that they would like to onto that scarf despite issuing an announcement 2013 on Twitter that those receipts, by the way, would be reduced in size. They said they're going to cut them down by 25 percent.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Still not enough.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: They're still -- there's still long. You stand there. It slows down the line, have you notice that, because everybody is waiting for these receipts to print. Well, they're having fun with it. You can buy a scarf now that looks like one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what, I don't even buy toilet paper at CVS anymore. I just get the receipt.

utterances.speaker: PAVLOV
utterances.utterance: That's very economical.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Katie. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So it's my turn.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes. An alarmed neighbor heard this happening and call the police. Take a listen.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Let me out. Let me out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What's going on?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: All right, so you can hear someone saying, let me out, help. And thinking a woman was screaming in the house and being held captive, the neighbor called because any good neighbor does that. But it turned out to be a parrot. And four officers responded to the Florida residence.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: No way.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The parrot's owner was working in his driveway. And he calmly said that the bird, Rambo -- this is what he said to the officers.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Come on.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: They don't have it. All right, anyways, he said that Rambo yell sometimes help, help, let me out because he taught him that as a kid because the bird is 40 years old so --

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: There you go. Good job, neighbor.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Did they check on the parrot just to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Maybe that was just a great story. Just the parrot, but don't go in the basement.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: All right, so you've heard of people seeing the Virgin Mary on a piece of toast, but what about a manatee on a chicken nugget. All right, so a Florida woman bought this chicken nugget at a local grocery store, and now she's selling it online for $5,000. If you don't think it resembles a manatee, Melinda says it looks better in person and that any proceeds from the sale will be donated to manatee related charities.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: But she got sauce? Free sauce?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: It's crazy. $5,000?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'd bid $1,500 tops for that very, very cute little manatee. All right, speaking of manatee, set your DVRs. "SPECIAL REPORT" up next.
